data.title: Rebuild packages fails in Beta
data.body: Similar to https://github.com/atom/atom/issues/8837, however this only happens with the Atom Beta build, no _Incompatible Package_ issues in stable build. Upon opening Atom, even in safe mode, a red bug icon appears. The screen it leads to reveals that > Some installed packages could not be loaded because they contain native modules that were compiled for earlier version of Atom. Clicking the button to `Rebuild Packages` fails giving the errors shown below. Note the target path for the Make command is odd and seems to point to the non-beta version. `../../../../../../../../../../../../Applications/Atom` ![screen shot 2015-11-13 at 19 03 10](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/1646307/11155004/9e33161c-8a3a-11e5-90e0-41f047edeaeb.png) If i navigate to the package folder and run the rebuild command, it succeeds with `apm` but fails with `ape-beta` giving same output as above. This is on OS X 10.11.1, running NVM if it makes a difference.

data.title: If atom is launched on non-primary monitor, dropdowns appear in wrong place
data.body:
1. Open atom on non-primary screen ( You do this by moving terminal to non primary screen, and typing "atom ." to launch)
2. go to preferences -> Settings, go to "Tab length", click dropwdon
3. Notice that drop down appears in wrong place, or doesn't appear ( likely due to rendering off screen)
4. Drag atom to primary screen
5. Click dropdown, notice it is positioned properly
6. Drag atom back to non-primary monitor
7. Click tab length dropdown
8. Notice it works properly now.

Atom 1.1.0

uname -a: 
Linux lnx-daniel 3.13.0-37-generic #64-Ubuntu SMP Mon Sep 22 21:28:38 UTC 2014 x86_64 x86_64 x86_64 GNU/Linux

/etc/lsb-release
DISTRIB_ID=LinuxMint
DISTRIB_RELEASE=17.1
DISTRIB_CODENAME=rebecca
DISTRIB_DESCRIPTION="Linux Mint 17.1 Rebecca"

data.title: Auto-update doesn't work (OS X)
data.body:
When opening Atom, it automatically starts a download of the new version Atom 1.2.0.

After a while, I get the option in the menu to "Restart and Install Update". Atom closes, but when it opens again it's back at "Downloading Update" and the version is still 1.1.0.

No matter how many times I try, I'm stuck in this cycle.

I thought that the package [sync-settings](https://atom.io/packages/sync-settings) might be the offender, but I still have this problem after disabling it. Besides that, I don't have any particular packages of interest to note.

data.title: Atom wants to downgrade itself from the latest version
data.body:
The blue squirrel icon at the bottom right lit up today, so I clicked it.
![screen shot 2015-11-13 at 10 26 45 am](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/577345/11153973/32000a20-89f1-11e5-9574-976fedfe36b1.png)
It shows an update to 1.1.0 being available as of the October 29. But I was pretty sure I updated Atom more recently than that. The Atom menu says that I'm on 1.2.0! If I click the "Check for Update" button, I get this:
![screen shot 2015-11-13 at 10 26 53 am](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/577345/11154001/660851ec-89f1-11e5-861a-787eb1d06396.png)
Was the latest version of Atom rolled back for some reason? I think I'm just going to avoid "updating" for now.

data.title: Editor crashes when I try to save a new file
data.body:
I've been using Atom for several weeks (on windows 7) with no issue but now, when I try to add a folder or file to my project directory, a window appears saying the editor has crashed offering three options:
close, reload, leave open
If I choose the option to leave it open, the window goes white. Any thoughts?

data.title: Set initialLoadComplete to true only in test mode
data.body:
Fixes #9189 

After the changes in #8968, `ThemeManager::isInitialLoadComplete` [was always being set to true](https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/src/atom-environment.coffee#L185-L186), whereas in the past we used to set it only after all the theme packages had been activated.

How does this relate to scrollbars? When restoring the previous state we attach the workspace along with the needed `TextEditorElement`s. When `TextEditorComponent` gets instantiated, it uses `isInitialLoadComplete` to decide whether it should listen to `ThemeManager::onDidChangeActiveThemes`, which is what triggers `::refreshScrollbars` after e.g. `one-dark-ui` loads.

Since `::isInitialLoadComplete` was true before the themes had the chance to actually being loaded, we weren't refreshing scrollbars at all, thus not allowing webkit to apply the needed stylesheets (when we refresh the scrollbars we explicitly trigger a reflow to let Chrome handle stylesheets correctly).

This PR changes the existing behavior so that we mark the initial theme load as complete only in test mode (through a configurable option).

/cc: @nathansobo @atom/feedback

data.title: When opening multiple files Atom (1.3.0.beta0) creates a new window for each file
data.body:
In Atom 1.2.0 when I opened a lot of files at once from the finder it was just adding them to a previously opened window. Now I'm trying the version 1.3.0.beta0 and it created a new window for each file, each of them having the folder the file was into as the project folder.

This is the result:

![](http://s24.postimg.org/t05v8vdlh/Screen_Shot_2015_11_13_at_17_27_14.png)

Every white rectangle is an Atom window, a crashed one. Is it a bug or a minded change? If so I'd like to point out that those files where all part of a folder that had already an Atom window, if you want to keep this "feature" at least you should notice it, and in that case attach them to the already opened window.

data.title: atom 1.2.0 release cannot start as root
data.body:
just upgraded to 1.2.0 release and suddenly can't run as root.

this is on an Ubuntu 14.04 fresh install

1.1.0 does not have this issue

data.title: Possible Startup Improvements
data.body:
This issue is aimed at listing and evaluating some speedups we could potentially employ on startup. The reported savings are somewhat suppositional, in that they may or may not represent the actual time we will end up saving.
### Breaking Startup Down

![breakdown](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/482957/11148370/b18ae820-8a1c-11e5-9456-edb230584f38.png)
### What could we attack?

| Operation | Cost | Potential Savings | Notes |
| :-: | :-: | :-: | :-: |
| JSON Parsing | 50ms | 30ms |  |
| Reading Less Cache | 40ms | 30ms |  |
| Resolving Modules | 56ms (?) | 50ms (?) | We suspect the require path takes much more than this, but it's hard to tell from the profiler. |
| Loading Grammars | 150ms | 100-120ms |  |
| Slow Reflows | 150ms | 100ms (?) | It's not clear whether Chrome needs to spend a fixed amount of time when it reflows stuff the first time. |
| Sync GitRepository | 45ms | 45ms |  |
| Electron Startup | 180ms | 100-120ms (?) | We may probably use the NativeCompileCache here as well, and speeding up the require path may help too. |
| - | - | - | - |
| **Total:** |  | 450-480ms |  |

Please, note that the speedups herein highlighted wouldn't _revolutionize_ the way Atom handles the above operations. This means that there are probably other ways in which we could make things faster by, for example, introducing breaking changes: this is outside the scope of this issue, though, as we're currently looking for optimizations that are safe and compatible with how things work as of today.

Also, there may be other chances to make startup faster by employing some hack to simply show an hidden window instead of reloading the whole environment: this, however, should probably be the subject of another issue, as it is a completely distinct approach.

/cc: @atom/feedback @nathansobo

data.title: ::shadow warnings in the console
data.body:
With Atom `1.2.0`.

In the console log, when Atom starts without any open file:

```
/deep/ combinator is deprecated. See https://www.chromestatus.com/features/6750456638341120 for more details.
```

In the console log, after opening a file:

```
[cut]\AppData\Local\atom\app-1.2.0\resources\app.asar\src\text-editor-component.…:919 ::shadow pseudo-element is deprecated. See https://www.chromestatus.com/features/6750456638341120 for more details.
```

data.title: Atom 1.2.0 (1.3.0-beta) JS and JSX syntax
data.body:
After upgrade to 1.2.0 all my `.js` files that were treated as `Javascript (JSX)` syntax are treated as `Javascript` and I need to manually switch every time I start to render.

I haven't found and toggles to make the change persitant. In the same time, it works totally fine in 1.1.0.

data.title: Atom 1.2.0 (1.3.0-beta) color schema changes.
data.body: Again as #9561 I appologize for not having good details, but after an upgrage I've noticed that JS color schema changed. Currenly I have 1.1.0 and 1.3.0-beta installed side by side. With having identitical plugins, JS file in 1.1.0 In 1.3.0-beta All variables become red with Javascript (JSX) language selected. It might seems as minor thing, but color schema changes (especially to that red color) is quite significant experience change, that I would like to avoid.

data.title: Atom 1.2.0 (1.3.0-beta) rendering is slow
data.body:
Sorry, for such subjective and non-technical bug description.

I've installed Atom 1.2.0 (as well as Atom 1.3.0-beta) yesterday. Release notes saying about performance improvements (both rending and startup time) that are hardly could be noticed.

1.2.0 (and 1.3.0-beta) rendering is very slow. What I mean, if I click some file, I first see the "grey" text and only after the coloring syntax applies. So, it blinks and for me it's really hurting experience.

Had to downgrade to 1.1.0 again. If I can provide more information, please let me know.

data.title: Services menu in OS X doesn't work
data.body:
I just installed Atom 1.2 on OS X 10.10 and noticed that the `Services` menu doesn't work. I use Automator script to control my music player, so without that menu I have no access to global OS X hotkeys when I'm in Atom. The `Services` menu item itself is present, but it has no submenu.

I'm not sure if this issue emerged after updating to Atom 1.2 or it existed before.

data.title: Uninstall button of plugins should ask for confirmation
data.body:
The "Uninstall" button of community plugins just remove, without asking for any confirmation.

![schermata 2015-11-13 alle 09 23 51](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/284924/11141722/4c2ad3fc-89e8-11e5-88ea-2b60aee54c05.png)

This can lead to errors when the users click it by mistake (for example: his intention was to click "Settings" or "Disable")

data.title: permission error on fuse directories
data.body:
I just upgraded to 1.2.0 and now I get a Permission error when trying to open anything, file or project, in my fuse directory.  In particular it is a directory mounted with objectivefs.  This did not happen on 1.1.0 or earlier.

Edit: I just verified it still works on 1.1.0

Atom 1.2.0
Ubuntu 12.04.5 LTS
apm  1.4.0
npm  2.13.3
node 0.10.40
python 2.7.3
git 1.7.9.5

data.title: Add a linux archive to distribute atom
data.body:
Now that Atom has a relocable/portable config directories and different channels, it makes sense to have a way to distribute an archive on Linux (as suggested on bug #7102) containing latest available code for each channels.

This has two advantages:
- this will enable (in a later step) to enable auto-upgrade to follow multiple channels (optionally in parallel in different directories). We can even think giving a way for people to switch between channels as needed (given the user config stay backward compatible). I'm happy to work on those 2 problematics after/if this PR is merged at some point.
- if all dependencies are installed in the distribution, the atom installation is then just a question of extracting an archive, requiring non root permission contrary to the .deb or .rpm packages.

We can then integrate this archive to be downloaded to some tools like Ubuntu Make (https://github.com/ubuntu/ubuntu-make/issues/6).

We generate a .tar.gz compressed archive (we could switch to a more performant .tar.xz, but the first format is more widespread and usual). I did add the `mktar` to the `CI task` (I saw the rpm wasn't in there, so I guess, it's only running on an Ubuntu machine) and tested it. I did add the task as well to `upload-assets`, but of course, I couldn't test it ;) The changes there are though minimal, but I can modify what's necessary as needed.

As _version_ contains _upstream version + channel name_, I didn't change anything in the naming of the archive publication, and the folder in archive contains thus an uniquely defined build.

Of course, the resulting archive is linked against the libraries available in the builder version. mktar is run where the .deb is built, which is, I guess, the latest ubuntu LTS. I tried the built archive on 14.04 LTS, 15.04, 15.10 and xenial (dev version), and everything is working as expected. If this doesn't work on other distros (which, looking at the deps, seems unlikely and we already only have one deb for debian/ubuntu and one rpm for fedora/opensuse…), we can build multiple archives. But I propose we starts with this one.

I'm happy to do any changes that you feel are necessary!

data.title: atom becomes unresponsive after opening a file with many lines
data.body:
To reproduce
1. Download and open [words.txt](https://github.com/atom/atom/files/33582/words.txt)
2. Attempt to scroll down. 

After several, 'Editor not responding...' messages, a 'Editor has crashed.' message will appear. 

1.3.0-dev-7bcdc9a

data.title: linter-eslint not running (even though installed)
data.body:
So I installed linter-eslint cause installing eslint result in this error:
No available version compatible with the installed Atom version: 1.1.0.
But at least linter-eslint is installed. but when I open atom this is what I get:
eslint binary not found locally, falling back to packaged one. Plugins won't be loaded and linting will possibly not work. (Try Use Global ESLint option, or install locally eslint to your project.)
 how to set global option? and I have eslint installed locally in my project but still it doesn't work
